episodes.title: #28 Metameta
episodes.description:
We pressed record straight in the middle of a friendship checkup about last week's cancer updates. If you want to see two therapists in live action you are in for a treat. Plus get a preview for the project Jennifer has been dreaming up and end with a brief discussion on the best terminology in high control religious dynamics. You know...our typical topics of choice. :)

00:22 Exploring Meta Communication
02:36 Reflecting on Last Episode
03:40 Cancer and Vulnerability
04:28 Dealing with Mortality

episodes.title: #27 Summer Recap
episodes.description: Welcome back from a whirlwind summer! Jennifer and Aleesa catch up on life and talk through some ideas for the upcoming podcasts. What do you want to hear about? Book reviews, control dynamics in therapy, parables with bad advice? We've got you covered for all of the random ramblings about psychology, religion, and philosophy with a little bit of politics on the side. School is back in session and we are ready to go!

episodes.title: #26 Fundamentalist Parenting
episodes.description:
Fundamentalist parenting shows its true colors in practices like blanket training—rigid, non-age-appropriate demands enforced through emotional and physical punishment, all wrapped in a bow of celebration.

If that’s not the blueprint for high-control religion, what is?

We break it down with real-life examples (yes, the Duggars), and explore how parenting becomes a tool for control. Let’s unpack it together.

episodes.title: #25 The Charismatic Leader Continuum
episodes.description: In this episode, we’re diving into the strange allure of fundamentalism and charismatic leaders like Mark Driscoll—why they are so magnetic, how they keep people coming back, and what it reveals about power, control, and the need for certainty. Buckle up, we are going on a birthday edition ride through the weeds.

episodes.title: #24 Fundamentalism Part Two
episodes.description:
We're back with Part Two of our deep dive into fundamentalism!
This time, we're talking spiritual warfare, casting spells, and the whole "soldier for God" mindset. We even stir in a dash of politics and drop some therapy tips for anyone breaking free from the fundamentalist grind.

episodes.title: #23 Chat GPT Love Letter
episodes.description: Jennifer surprises Aleesa with an uplifting message from ChatGPT—will Aleesa finally be impressed by the world of AI? Jennifer reflects on how her experience with cancer has transformed her outlook on life, and why scheduling time for awe and wonder means that she's been trying to seeing into outer space in broad daylight.

episodes.title: #22 Fundamentalism Part 1
episodes.description:
In Fundamentalism Part 1, Jennifer kicks things off with a thought-provoking breakdown of the "recipe" for fundamentalism—what it is, how it works, and why it persists. The hosts dive into the historical, social, and even biblical expressions of fundamentalism, asking big questions like: Can you be a fringe fundamentalist? Has fundamentalism always been around? And… was Jesus a fundamentalist?

Don’t miss the unforgettable recipe-themed intro and outro—it’s the perfect flavor combo of insight, humor, and critical thought. This is the first slice of a multi-part conversation you won’t want to miss.

episodes.title: #21 There's the Playbook
episodes.description: In this episode, Jennifer and Aleesa dive into yet another culty group—and surprise, surprise... it’s the same old story. 👀 From love bombing to control tactics, Jennifer’s got her favorite line locked and loaded: "There's the playbook!"Because yep—it’s always the same moves with these groups. This week, we unpack how religion can tap into our deepest human needs—like the longing for meaning, purpose, and belonging—only to twist those into tools of manipulation and harm. All under the guise of being "a good thing." Tune in as we break it down with insight, honesty, and just the right amount of sass. Let’s talk about it.

episodes.title: #20 Do We Have Trust Issues?
episodes.description: In this episode we dive into the importance of therapists being in therapy themselves. We share personal experiences, the ups and downs of being both provider and client, and why being on the receiving end of therapy is essential for doing the work well. We also explore whether trust issues are a barrier—or actually a helpful tool—in the therapeutic process, offering honest reflections and a few pieces of advice along the way.

episodes.title: Power Dynamics are Everywhere
episodes.description: Jennifer and Aleesa dive back into the world of high-control dynamics—whether in church groups or therapy rooms. What if churches came with a shrink-wrapped label, clearly advertising how much personal autonomy you're actually allowed? And when it comes to therapy, where’s the perfect balance between authority and competency—without tipping into control? They also unpack the eerie similarities between the phrase 'You are broken, and only I can fix you' in both religious and therapeutic spaces.  And—controversial take—could gossip actually be a good thing? Let’s get into it!

episodes.title: #18 Friendship in the Wild
episodes.description: Making friends as an adult is hard enough—but what happens when you're starting fresh outside of religion? In this episode, Aleesa and Jennifer share their wins and fails in the search for meaningful connections. Is the PTA a goldmine for new friendships or just another obligation? What about the gym—social hotspot or solo zone? Stick around until the halfway mark, where they each break down the top five places for meeting new people and give them a final grade. You might be surprised by the results!

episodes.title: #17 Interpersonal Violence
episodes.description: In this episode, we dive into the complicated relationship between churches and interpersonal violence—both when they contribute to the problem and when they try to help. First, we break down how religious leadership can sometimes follow a high-control ‘playbook’ that keeps people trapped in harmful cycles. Then, Aleesa unpacks what it looks like when churches actually step up to address these issues. We explore why prioritizing victim safety and sharing accurate information matters way more than churches trying to handle abuse without the right expertise.

episodes.title: #15 Spiral Dynamics Part Two
episodes.description: "We're diving back into Spiral Dynamics, unpacking its insights—until an unexpected guest shakes up the conversation! Along the way, we wrestle with big questions like: Do you believe getting what you want means taking from someone else? And how does Spiral Dynamics help us make sense of today’s political trends? Stick around to the end for the song that's been carrying us through this season of life."

episodes.title: #16 Combatting Cult Mind Control Book Review
#14 Spiral Dynamics
episodes.description: Today, Jennifer is taking Aleesa (and all of you) on a deep dive into Spiral Dynamics—a rainbow-colored model for understanding human development, both individually and collectively. Don’t worry, we’re bringing our cult radar along for the ride, too. And in predictable form there's some places where the model is less academic/psychology and more opportunistic "guru bro" MLM vibe. Nonetheless if you’ve got even 1/100th of Jennifer’s enthusiasm for psychology talk, you’re in for a treat. And if this episode leaves you wanting more, check out Rob Bell's 4 Part Series "Me We Everybody" at https://open.spotify.com/episode/7IB6jHlfPM8d0rMmtE9v0k?si=2b7bfa25b5294ed3 or the book Spiral Dynamics by Beck and Cowan.

episodes.title: Is this America's Most Dangerous Cult?
episodes.description: We discuss the book "Broken Faith: Inside one of America's Most Dangerous Cults" by Mitch Weiss and Holbrook Moore, which examines the Word of Faith Fellowship in North Carolina. The group, led by Jane Whitley, is accused of various abuses, including physical and emotional manipulation, and has successfully evaded lawsuits and criminal charges. We’ll break down the BITE model (no, not vampires, but mind control), unpack how people escape high-control groups, and explore why lawsuits seem to bounce off this church like a rubber ball.

episodes.title: Is this America's Most Dangerous Cult?
episodes.description: We discuss the book "Broken Faith: Inside one of America's Most Dangerous Cults" by Mitch Weiss and Holbrook Moore, which examines the Word of Faith Fellowship in North Carolina. The group, led by Jane Whitley, is accused of various abuses, including physical and emotional manipulation, and has successfully evaded lawsuits and criminal charges. We’ll break down the BITE model (no, not vampires, but mind control), unpack how people escape high-control groups, and explore why lawsuits seem to bounce off this church like a rubber ball.

episodes.title: Testing Culty Groups with the BITE Model
episodes.description: Today, we’re putting the BITE Model of authoritarian control under the microscope to see just how culty their former religious groups really were. From behavior policing to thought control, we’ll rank their experiences on a scale from “quirky summer camp” to “run for the hills.” Buckle up for real-life examples, a few cringey confessions, and the occasional existential laugh—you’ll never look at “community small groups” the same way again. Take the test yourself at Bitemodel.com

episodes.title: Cults
episodes.description: Cults. What makes them tick? Unique traits, shared tactics, and psychological impact. We also dig into how high-control groups can shape our own lives and mindsets. Join us as we take turns unpacking cult group examples and share some personal insights along the way!

episodes.title: Love Bombing
episodes.description:
"Love Bombing: When Affection is a Trap"

In this episode, we explore lovebombing—a tactic used in cults and manipulative relationships to overwhelm someone with affection and attention. We’ll discuss how it differs from healthy love, why it’s so effective, and the red flags to watch for in both cult groups and romantic relationships. Join us for a casual, insightful chat about how to recognize and protect yourself from emotional manipulation.

episodes.title: Cognitive Dissonance
episodes.description: Today, we’re digging into cognitive dissonance – that oh-so-familiar feeling when your beliefs and actions just don’t get along. We’ll be swapping our own embarrassing stories, talking election season (because who isn't dissonant there?), and playing armchair psychologist. Buckle up, because it turns out, reality has layers... and not all of them agree!"
